results.adx_keywords: Books and Literature;Marriages;Love (Emotion);Dating and Relationships;Chapman, Gary (1938- )
results.byline: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta and Luis Mazon
results.title: The Sixth Love Language Does Not Exist
results.abstract: The author of the seminal book on love languages is surprised that the concept has become a cultural phenomenon. But he still wants couples to heed his advice.

media.caption: Karolyn and Gary Chapman at their wedding reception in August 1961. The couple, who have been married for over 60 years, said they had a rocky start.

results.title: In Finland, a Partying Prime Minister Draws Tuts, and Cheers
results.abstract: Leaked videos featuring Sanna Marin dancing have raised the question of whether she is held to a different standard than older, male leaders are.

media.caption: Prime Minister Sanna Marin of Finland.

results.title: Octopuses Don’t Have Backbones — or Rights
results.abstract: As cephalopods become more important in neuroscience and other fields, scientists and welfare advocates seek to give the smart animals the same protections as mice and monkeys.

media.caption: More octopuses and other cephalopods are being used in labs, where federal animal welfare laws do not apply to them.

results.adx_keywords: Travel and Vacations;Art;Pop and Rock Music;Restaurants;Culture (Arts);Food;Boston (Mass)
results.title: New Faces, New Places, as Boston Gets Revitalized
results.abstract: In New England’s largest city, there are exciting music venues, a floating oyster bar and newcomers on the arts and restaurant scenes that reflect its diversity.

media.caption: “Breathe Life Together,” a mural by Rob Gibbs, who paints under the name ProBlak, now overlooks Dewey Square in Boston, near South Station.

results.title: Your Doppelgänger Is Out There and You Probably Share DNA With Them
results.abstract: That person who looks just like you is not your twin, but if scientists compared your genomes, they might find a lot in common.

media.caption: Charlie Chasen and Michael Malone, Atlanta, 2014.

results.adx_keywords: Tennis;Content Type: Personal Profile;United States Open (Tennis);Ovarian Cancer;Breast Cancer;Evert, Chris;Evert Dubin, Jeanne (1957-2020)
results.title: Chris Evert Needs Everyone to Listen
results.abstract: Since January, the 18-time Grand Slam champion has balanced her work in tennis with the grueling routine of chemotherapy for ovarian cancer. She never would have caught it early, if she hadn’t lost her sister to the same disease.

media.copyright: Melanie Metz for The New York Times

results.title: How to Get Published: A Book’s Journey From ‘Very Messy’ Draft to Best Seller
results.abstract: The mainstream publishing industry is intimidating. How does a writer break in? Follow Jessamine Chan’s “The School for Good Mothers” through the roller coaster of its creation.

results.adx_keywords: Art;Photography;Johnson, Ray (1927-95);Morgan Library & Museum;Manhattan (NYC)
results.title: Ray Johnson’s Camera Was Disposable. The Photos Are Unforgettable.
results.abstract: The Pop artist spent his final years taking pictures and kept them a secret. Dozens are on view in a revelatory show at the Morgan Library & Museum.

media.caption: “RJ with Please Send to Real Life and Camera in Mirror,” Dec. 23, 1994, a self-portrait of Ray Johnson that appears on a roll of film he turned in for developing about three weeks before his death in 1995.
media.copyright: Ray Johnson/Artists Rights Society (ARS), New York; via the Morgan Library & Museum

results.adx_keywords: Therapy and Rehabilitation;Depression (Mental);Anxiety and Stress;Emotions;Teenagers and Adolescence;Suicides and Suicide Attempts;Mental Health and Disorders;Psychology and Psychologists;Content Type: Service;Parenting;your-feed-health;American Academy of Pediatrics
results.title: ‘The Best Tool We Have’ for Self-Harming and Suicidal Teens
results.abstract: Studies indicate that dialectical behavior therapy offers greater benefits than more generalized therapy. But treatment is intensive, and expensive.

media.caption: “There’s no medication for suicidal behavior,” said Michele Berk, a psychologist at Stanford University. “The patient needs to learn other behavioral skills that the medication does not teach you.”
media.copyright: Anastasiia Sapon for The New York Times

results.title: Greek Party Islands Chill Out
results.abstract: For years, Santorini, Mykonos and Ios have been known for their embrace of excess. But some new operators on Greece’s Cycladic Islands want to break that cycle.

media.caption: The sun sets on Oia, a village in Santorini, where resort operators are now inviting tourists to put up their feet and lean into a version of wellness that hinges on slowing down.
media.copyright: Maria Mavropoulou for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Colleges and Universities;Admissions Standards;Affirmative Action;Race and Ethnicity;Discrimination;Minorities;Black People;University of Michigan;University of California;Harvard University;University of North Carolina;Supreme Court (US)
results.title: Affirmative Action Was Banned at Two Top Universities. They Say They Need It.
results.abstract: As a Supreme Court case on college admissions nears, the California and Michigan university systems say their efforts to build diverse classes have hardly worked.

media.caption: The University of Michigan stated that despite “persistent, vigorous and varied efforts” to diversify its student body, the enrollment of underrepresented minority students has “fallen precipitously” at many of its schools.
media.copyright: Joshua Lott for The New York Times

results.title: On Remote Farms and in City Gardens, a Native American Movement Grows
